newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Arafat says he expects Israel to close tunnel.
newsitem.headline: Arafat says he expects Israel to close tunnel.

text.p: President Yasser Arafat said Palestinian anger would fade if Israel closed a controversial tunnel but he did not want to meet Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu unless it would advance the peace process.

"The closing of the tunnel would show prudent judgment. We expect the situtation at the tunnel to go back to the way it was. Then the storm will fade," he told Israel's Yedioth Ahronoth newspaper in an interview published on Sunday.
Since the opening of the tunnel, showing ancient ruins revered by Jews but running near Islamic sites, 55 Palestinians and 14 Israelis have died in clashes.

Arafat said he was ready to meet Netanyahu one-on-one if Israel closed the tunnel and set a timetable for implementing Israeli-Palestinian peace accords. But he said there was no point in a meeting for the sake of meeting.

Palestinians hurled stones at Israeli police on Sunday at the reopening of the tourist tunnel near the al-Aqsa mosque, Islam's third holiest site. The tunnel had been closed for two days for the Jewish sabbath.
Israeli workmen last week punched a second entrance in the tunnel, saying it would allow more visits. The opening prompted Palestinian protests and international condemnation.

Netanyahu accused Arafat of "cynically" exploiting the tunnel issue. Palestinians called the opening an Israeli attempt to "Judaise" Arab East Jerusalem, occupied by Israel in the 1967 Middle East war.
Arafat said Netanyahu -- elected in May on a promise to take a hard line on Israeli security -- had "hurled a bomb".

"The conflict between us is political," Arafat said. "When the religious element is added, it's hard to control the situation. Does Netanyahu know this?" Arafat said in the interview conducted on Saturday.

He denied charges by some Israeli politicians that Palestinian police were ordered to fire on Israeli soldiers: "When our police opened fire, it was only because they felt endangered and protected themselves."
He said his police had been armed to fight violent opponents of the peace process and maintain order. "What would they have us arm it (the police) with -- toy pistols?"
Arafat said Netanyahu had proposed in a phone call from Germany, where the Israeli leader was on an official visit last week, that they meet together with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak.
The Palestinian leader said he was ready for such a meeting, even if it included American and European officials.
He brushed aside Netanyahu's assertion that earlier meetings Netanyahu and other Israeli cabinet ministers held with him amounted to progress.

"With Netanyahu everything begins and ends with a meeting. I hope the situation will change. I propose a challenge to Netanyanu: to make public the protocol of our meeting, and then everybody will know that the meeting didn't move us forward," Arafat said.
